text:
On my first i used a mortgage broker to double stamp the source of funds and I have continued working so have an income to get a mortgage.
However never mention betting as you will get rejected, you don't want any transactions on your bank accounts as well so don't use your main and ideally layer it through paypal.

text:
I did exactly this. Buying a house for "cash" certainly raised a few eyebrows at the solicitors but I'd invested all of my money in shares and a portfolio of managed stock funds which had been returning 10%-40% annual interest for about 15 years. Better than gambling to be honest.
But MUCH less fun.

elements.text:
I did exactly this. Buying a house for "cash" certainly raised a few eyebrows at the solicitors but I'd invested all of my money in shares and a portfolio of managed stock funds which had been returning 10%-40% annual interest for about 15 years. Better than gambling to be honest.
But MUCH less fun.

text: My solicitor was fine with gambling funds - I just got a letter from BF and that was all they needed.

elements.text: My solicitor was fine with gambling funds - I just got a letter from BF and that was all they needed.

text:
I'd been drip feeding into my investments, so didn't touch any betfair funds when buying, but it's useful to know that they can provide proof of income.
My funniest moment was when the solicitor asked how I was funding the purchase and I said "Cash, in a carrier bag. Would you prefer Aldi or Waitrose?" I'll never forget the look on her face. :joy:

text: At the end of the day it’s the solicitor who signs it off and the bank who is giving you the mortgage to run checks, this is where a broker can come in handy as some banks are more thorough on checks :wink:

text: Yeah I would highly recommend going via a broker, you can also be a lot more open with them about the situation than you could be going to a bank

elements.text: Yeah I would highly recommend going via a broker, you can also be a lot more open with them about the situation than you could be going to a bank

text:
Yep, I went with a broker in the past for a mortgage and they were very helpful. (I used John Charcol). Just be very honest about your situation. They know exactly what checks and information each bank needs so they can advise on the best choice. 

Re: bank accounts, I’d advise withdrawing winnings into an established bank account so it has less chance of raising alarms. I’ve heard that banks are getting stricter with money laundering checks, and my accountant says having somewhere to withdraw money to is becoming a bigger problem for big winners than actually winning the money is. It may actually be better to create a new account to receive your work income for 3-6 months for the mortgage application than to switch where you’re transferring winnings. 

Some mortgage lenders will want to see statements from all your bank accounts and some just your current account where you receive your work income. The brokers will know.

elements.text: Yep, I went with a broker in the past for a mortgage and they were very helpful. (I used John Charcol). Just be very honest about your situation. They know exactly what checks and information each bank needs so they can advise on the best choice.

Re: bank accounts, I’d advise withdrawing winnings into an established bank account so it has less chance of raising alarms. I’ve heard that banks are getting stricter with money laundering checks, and my accountant says having somewhere to withdraw money to is becoming a bigger problem for big winners than actually winning the money is. It may actually be better to create a new account to receive your work income for 3-6 months for the mortgage application than to switch where you’re transferring winnings.
Some mortgage lenders will want to see statements from all your bank accounts and some just your current account where you receive your work income. The brokers will know.

text: Yes, my accountant has a background in it. I think some banks just don’t want the hassle of money laundering risk whether they believe you or not and so would just rather not have the customer. I’ve been fine personally, but that’s just what I’ve heard. I have another long running bank account as back up just in case my usual one decides to change it’s mind at some point though. I’ve been meaning to set up another one too. Best to plan ahead.

text:
Curious, what would an accountant do for gamblers? Is it mainly capital gains tax on investments?
Are you saying you can’t just bank anywhere because some don’t want todo the laundering checks?

elements.text:
Curious, what would an accountant do for gamblers? Is it mainly capital gains tax on investments?
Are you saying you can’t just bank anywhere because some don’t want todo the laundering checks?

text:
For me (and most other individual gamblers), nothing special, just peace of mind if HMRC were to audit me I know I have someone with experience to respond for me. For big syndicates, a good accountant is probably very important to build the right company structure to avoid taxes and so on. 

I imagine receiving lots of money from gambling on a consistent basis would raise question marks from many people (including some banks) who don’t understand the industry. 

Part of me wonders whether my bank just doesn’t know it’s gambling related. My Betfair withdrawals appear as “sporting exch client” rather than “Betfair” on my statement. I think that’s because larger withdrawals go through a different pipeline to smaller withdrawals. So maybe the name doesn’t get flagged up? :man-shrugging:

text: I'm still sorting out exactly what structures to use (I'm in Australia). But for me it might be hard not to classify it as a business given that I am doing the same thing for myself as I did for clients. The only difference is that instead of being paid hourly, I will now be paid dependent on system winnings. There are a myriad of other factors involved, and everyone has different circumstances. Hence my only advice is to get specific advice from professionals related to your own circumstances
